questiontext.text:
Engineering Example 2


The web-flange junction
Introduction

In problems of torsion, the torsion constant, \(J\), which is a function of the shape and structure of the element under consideration, is an important quantity. A common beam section is the thick \( I\) -section shown here,

for which the torsion constant is given by

\[J = 2J_1 + J_2 + 2 \alpha D^4\]

where the \(J_1\) and \(J_2\) terms refer to the flanges and web respectively, and the \(D^4\) term refers to the web-flange junction. In fact

\[\alpha = \min \left[ \dfrac{t_f}{t_w}, \dfrac{t_w}{t_f} \right] \left( 0.15 + 0.1 \, \dfrac{r}{t_f} \right)\]

where \(t_f\) and \(t_w\) are the thicknesses of the flange and web respectively, and \(r\) is the radius of the concave circle element between the flange and the web. \(D\) is the diameter of the circle of the web-flange junction.

As \(D\) occurs in the form \(D^4\), the torsion constant is very sensitive to it. Calculation of \(D\) is therefore a crucial part of the calculation of \(J\).

Problem in words
Find \(D\), the diameter of the circle within the web--flange junction as a function of the other dimensions of the structural element.
Mathematical statement of problem
  1. Find \(D\), the diameter of the circle, in terms of \(t_f\) and \(t_w\) (the thicknesses of the flange and the web respectively) in the case where \(r=0\). When \(t_f = 3 \mbox{ cm}\) and \(t_w = 2 \mbox{ cm}\), find \(D\).
  2. For \(r \neq 0\), find \(D\) in terms of \(t_f\), \(t_w\) and \(r\). In the special case where \(t_f = 3 \mbox{ cm}\), \(t_w = 2 \mbox{ cm}\) and \(r = 0.4 \mbox{ cm}\), find \(D\).
Mathematical analysis
  1. Consider a co-ordinate system based on the midpoint of the outer surface of the flange.

    The centre of the circle will lie at \(( 0, -R)\) where \(R\) is the radius of the circle, i.e. \(R = D/2\). The equation of the circle is

    \[\begin{equation}\tag{1}x^2 + (y + R)^2 = R^2.\end{equation}\]

    In addition, the circle passes through the `corner' at point \(A = (t_w/2, -t_f)\), so

    \[\begin{equation}\tag{2} \left( \dfrac{t_w}{2} \right)^2 + (-t_f + R)^2 = R^2.\end{equation}\] On expanding \[\dfrac{t_w^2}{4} + t_f^2 - 2 R t_f + R^2 = R^2 \] giving \[2 R t_f = \dfrac{t_w^2}{4} + t_f^2\qquad\implies\quad R = \dfrac{(t_w^2/4) + t_f^2}{2t_f}= \frac{t_w^2}{8t_f} + \dfrac{t_f}{2} \] so that \[\begin{equation}\tag{3}D = 2R = \dfrac{t_w^2}{4t_f} + t_f\end{equation}.\] Setting \(t_f = 3 \mbox{ cm}\), \(t_w = 2 \mbox{ cm}\) gives \[s D = \frac{2^2}{4 \times 3} + 3 = 3.33 \mbox{ cm}\]

  2. Again using a co-ordinate system based on the mid-point of the outer surface of the flange, consider now the case \(r \neq 0\).

    Point \(B = (t_w/2+r,-t_f-r)\) lies, not on the circle described by (1), but on the slightly larger circle with the same centre, and radius \(R+r\). The equation of this circle is

    \[\begin{equation}\tag{4} x^2 + (y + R)^2 = (R+r)^2 .\end{equation}\]

    Putting the co-ordinates of point \(B\) into equation (4) gives

    \[\begin{equation}\tag{5}\left( \frac{t_w}{2}+r\right)^2 + \left(-t_f-r+R\right)^2 = \left(R+r\right)^2 \end{equation}\] which, on expanding gives \[ \dfrac{t_w^2}{4} + t_wr + r^2 + t_f^2 + r^2 + R^2 + 2t_fr - 2t_fR - 2rR = R^2 + 2rR + r^2 \] Cancelling and gathering terms gives \[\dfrac{t_w^2}{4} + t_wr + r^2 + t_f^2 + 2t_fr = 4rR + 2t_fR = 2R \left( 2r + t_f\right)\] so that \[2R = D = \dfrac{(t_w^2/4) + t_wr + r^2 + t_f^2 + 2t_fr}{(2r + t_f)}\] so \[\begin{equation}\tag{6} D=\dfrac{t_w^2 + 4t_wr + 4r^2 + 4t_f^2 + 8t_fr}{(8r + 4t_f)}\end{equation}\]

    Now putting \(t_f =3 \mbox{ cm}, t_w = 2 \mbox{ cm}\) and \(r = 0.4 \mbox{ cm}\) makes

    \[D = \frac{2^2 + (4\times2\times0.4) + (4\times0.4^2) + (4\times3^2) + (8\times3\times0.4)}{(8\times0.4) + (4\times3)} = \frac{53.44}{15.2} = 3.52 \mbox{ cm}\]
Interpretation

Note that setting \(r = 0\) in Equation (6) recovers the special case of \(r = 0\) given by equation (3). The value of \(D\) is now available to be used in calculations of the torsion constant, \(J\).
